MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Births, Deaths and Marriages.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will state the following: (a) the number of registered marriages for year 1950, (b) the number per 1,000 of population represented by that figure and (c) the number per 1,000 of population in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland of registered marriages.

Speaker.hpid: Parliamentary Secretary to the Taoiseach (Donnchadh Ó Briain) Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.NameTxt: Parliamentary Secretary to the Taoiseach (Donnchadh Ó Briain)
Speaker.P: The number of marriages registered in the year 1950 was 16,173 which represents a rate of 5.4 per thousand per annum. The corresponding rates were for England, 8.2, for Wales 8.0 and for Scotland 7.8. These figures are provisional and no data are available for the Six Counties.

asked the Taoiseach if he will state (a) the number of deaths registered in year 1950, (b) the number per 1,000 of population represented by that figure, (c) the number of deaths per 1,000 of population for year 1950 in England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, (d) the number of deaths in 1950 from cancer, (e) the number of deaths in 1950 from tuberculosis of all kinds, and (f) the disease that caused the next highest number of deaths.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The number of deaths registered in the country in 1950 was 37,835, which represents a rate of 12.6 per 1,000 per annum. The corresponding rates were: for England 11.6, for Wales 12.7 and for Scotland 12.4. The data for the Six Counties are not available. The number of deaths in the State in 1950 returned as from cancer was 3,903 and the number from tuberculosis of all kinds was 2,353. All the figures quoted for 1950 are provisional.

The complete classification of deaths by cause for the year 1950 is not yet available but normally heart disease accounts for a number of deaths in any year greatly in excess of the two specified causes and the single class with the greatest total is usually diseases of the myocardium.

asked the Taoiseach whether he will give the figures for (a) the number of births registered in year 1950; (b) the rate per 1,000 of population that the births represented and the similar figures for England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland; (c) the number of children who died in 1950 of one year or under; (d) the rate per 1,000 of population that figure represents and similar figures for England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, and (e) the main cause of death in children of under one year in Ireland and Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The number of births registered in the year 1950 was 63,263 which represents a rate of 21.0 per 1,000 per annum. The corresponding rates were for England 15.8, for Wales 16.3 and for Scotland 17.9. In that year the number of deaths of infants under one year of age was 2,866 which represents a rate of 0.97 per 1,000 per annum. The corresponding rates were for England 0.47, for Wales 0.58 and for Scotland 0.69. The figures quoted are provisional and data for the Six Counties are not available.

The complete classification for 1950 of deaths by cause is not yet available, but the principal cause of death of infants under one year of age in 1947-49 was premature birth and for the preceeding six years diarrhoea and enteritis. In England, Wales, Scotland and the Six Counties the principal cause of death of such infants has normally of recent years been premature birth.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Classification of Aliens.

Speaker.P: asked the Taoiseach if he will indicate what nationals are classified as “aliens” in census returns and if the classification of “aliens” does not include British nationals the number of people born in Britain (England, Scotland and Wales) who have taken up residence in Ireland from 1939 to 1950, inclusive.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The classification at the Irish censuses of population is by place of birth and not by nationality.

At the limited census of population taken in 1951 no question regarding place of birth of the population was asked. At the 1946 census, of the 49,444 residents who returned their birth place as in England, Wales and Scotland (including the Isle of Man and the Channel Islands), 11,155 were resident in the State less than seven years.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Quality of Rationed Tea.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Desmond Mr. Desmond Mr. Kyne Mr. Kyne
Speaker.P: and Mr. Desmond asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether he is aware that there are widespread complaints in connection with the quality of tea now sold at the ration price and, if so, if he will state if there are grounds for such complaints and whether he considers that tea of a better quality could be issued without an increase in price; and, if so, will he take steps to see that the quality is so improved.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lemass) Seán F. Lemass
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr. Lemass)
Speaker.P: My attention has been drawn to complaints about the quality of rationed tea published in the Journal of R.G.D.A.T.A. on February 10th, 1951. I understand that the quality is as satisfactory as possible having regard to the grades, types and price of tea available but some improvement may be possible when the new season teas are imported

Would the Minister be prepared to accept the statement of a reputable tea dealer that if a better quality of tea were made available, even at a higher price, it would eventually work out more cheaply because it would give 100 cups to the pound as against 50 cups to the pound in the case of the inferior tea, and that it would represent a saving to the people eventually? That is the definite view of the trade.
I think it is fairly correct to say that if a higher proportion of dearer teas were introduced the quality would be better but, of course, the price would be substantially higher.
Pro rata would not the price be cheaper ultimately?
I doubt that. All quality teas are purchased and sold in the prescribed proportions to the merchants responsible for the mixing of them.
The quality is very poor.
Would the Minister care to accept samples which have been sent to me by a reputable tea dealer, have them examined, and then say if he is prepared to accept the truth of the statement?

In the past year, of the total teas purchased, 43 per cent. were described as low grade, 41 per cent. as medium grade, and 16 per cent. as good. These different grades were mixed to get tea at the standard price. If we purchased more of the dearer grade, the quality would be better but the price would be substantially higher
But the yield would be better.
Could the Minister give any indication as to the quality of the standard tea being sold at the present rate as against the same standard of tea prior to 1939?

Would the Minister say if the arrangements for mixing the various grades are such as to ensure a uniform distribution of the different grades of tea? Traders and the public have the experience that at particular periods the quality falls below the normal standard.

It is possible that at the present time the teas being sold have been longer in stock than they would be at other periods of the year. Each wholesaler gets the same proportion of the different grades of tea and, presumably, it is in his own interest to make the best mixture in order to market tea of the highest quality. It is true that before 1939 we had all grades of tea sold at different prices by different merchants. Now there is a standard quality of tea sold at a standard price and, of course, that means that people who want to get a better quality tea at a higher price have not that opportunity.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Retailers and Bacon Supplies.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is aware that retailers of bacon are only supplied by one firm of curers conditionally on their paying an outrageous price for heads not even delivered, even though charged for their legitimate order at the full controlled price and if he will take adequate steps to eradicate this nefarious practice.
I am not aware of the alleged conditional sale of bacon by a particular firm. If the Deputy supplies me with the information at his disposal I will have the matter investigated.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Company Law Revision.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce what stage of progress has been reached in the revision and modernisation of company law and whether such revision will also include the revision of the Industrial and Friendly Societies Acts.

A committee is engaged in examining the question of company law reform. It is possible that a revision of company law would render desirable certain changes in the law relating to industrial and provident societies and friendly societies. Consideration of the matter generally must await the receipt and examination of the committee's report.
Has the Minister any idea when the committee will report?
I would not like to attempt a forecast.
Is there any possibility of getting an interim report?
It is hardly a subject that lends itself to that.
There are certain flagrant abuses that might be checked.
I will look into that.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Bacon Curers' Profits.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is aware that the last account of one firm of bacon curers shows an increase in profit of approximately 250 per cent. over the profit of the preceding year and if he has satisfied himself that such profits were reasonable in all the circumstances; and, if not, what action he proposes to take in reference to the matter.

I am not aware of the identity of the firm to which the Deputy refers but if he furnishes particulars to my Department I will look into the matter further. I should point out, however, that bacon prices were decontrolled in August, 1949 and control was not reimposed again until January of this year.
Particulars are in the R.G.D.A.T.A. Review.
In that case I should point out to the Deputy that the firm in question is engaged in many other activities and that bacon curing is a small part of its activities.
It is getting on fairly well anyway.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hides for Leather Factories.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether he is aware that the leather factories are being left short of hides due to the fact that dealers are under the impression that an increase is likely to be announced shortly by his Department; and, if so, if he will ease this hold-up by either announcing the increase or by definitely stating that it is not going to be granted.
I am aware that the supply of hides to tanneries is unsatisfactory at present. I am having the matter examined and I hope to be in a position to make an announcement at an early date.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Electricity Supply Board Pensions.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state when the increases in pensions granted by the Electricity Supply Board to transferred pensioners from the Dublin Corporation will be paid, and if he is aware that an undertaking given by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry and Commerce on the 27th June, 1950, has not been implemented.

asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state the reason why transferred corporation employees, pensioned by the Electricity Supply Board, have not had their pensions increased to date, also the cause of the delay in paying them the increase in the light of the many promises given in the past that the matter was receiving attention.
With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 10 and 11 together.

I am informed by the Electricity Supply Board that the increases in pensions authorised by Section 16 of the Pensions (Increase) Act, 1950, have been paid by the board. Legislation to deal with the case of other pensioners of the board, including some transferred to the service of the board from that of the Dublin Corporation, who are not covered by the Pensions (Increase) Act, 1950, is in course of preparation.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Rural Electrification in County Waterford.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether he will recommend to the Electricity Supply Board that a further re-examination of the question of bringing rural electrification service to the districts of Touraneena and Ballinamult, County Waterford, should be carried out, in view of the fact that it will facilitate, as well as the ordinary residents, the creameries in Ballinamult, Scart and Ballymacarbery and enable them to avail of the current for these important industries.

I am informed by the Electricity Supply Board that the Ballinamult rural area, which includes Touraneena, was considered for selection in May, 1951, with other areas in the Waterford district. The ratio of fixed charge revenue, however, did not compare favourably with that of other areas due mainly to the high percentage of householders—46 per cent.—who refused to take supply, and, accordingly, the Ballinamult rural area was not listed for early development.

The board state that this area will again be considered in the autumn of this year but the prospects of it being selected for development in priority to other areas, are not considered to be good unless a higher percentage of householders agree to accept supply.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Córas Iompair Éireann Employment Regulations.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Supplies of Anthracite.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state whether he can make available sufficient quantities of anthracite to meet the demand for heat storage cookers in the future.

I have no reason to doubt that sufficient quantities of anthracite will be available to meet the reasonable requirements of all users, but as we are dependent to some extent on imported supplies, no specific assurance can yet be given as to the quantities which will be available.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Lorry Services.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he is aware that licensees have great difficulty in obtaining efficient lorries within the weight limits permitted by the Road Transport Acts and if he will introduce proposals for legislation to remedy this situation.

From the information available to me, I am not satisfied that the holders of merchandise licences should have any undue difficulty in obtaining efficient lorries within the limits of the standard lorry weight specified in their licences, and consequently I do not consider there is any necessity for amending legislation in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Water Piping Supplies.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will take effective steps to secure the provision of adequate supplies of water piping to enable local authorities to proceed with the schemes of public utility already planned.
I assume the Deputy is referring to copper and lead pipes, and not to underground mains, the supply of which is at the moment satisfactory.

The supply position as regards copper and lead piping is very difficult. Home manufacturers are receiving only sufficient raw materials to meet about 50 per cent. of requirements in the case of copper, and 70 per cent. in the case of lead pipes. I am at present exploring how this position might be improved.

The Deputy was referring to underground mains, but through my own fault that was not made clear. The position is far from satisfactory. The Kildare County Council, for example, are told that there is going to be a delay of at least two years. Does the Minister consider that to be a satisfactory position in relation to the new water supply for the town of Newbridge?
Will the Minister bear in mind that this problem is common to every county, and that such water supplies are being held up in every county owing to the lack of these supplies?
Certainly, but the information available to me would seem to indicate that, so far as underground mains are concerned, the position is not unsatisfactory.
Would the Minister indicate to the Kildare County Council and, apparently, to the Cork County Council also where these supplies his Department say are available can be obtained?
Supplies of some sort can be obtained, but, of course, the particular type of pipe the county engineers may prefer may be in short supply.
We will not be able to get any type for two years.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Sligo Harbour.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he will state what is the present position as regards repairs to Sligo Harbour and when it is expected work will start there.

Plans and specifications for the proposed works at Sligo Harbour have been sent to the Sligo Harbour Commissioners for consideration and the other preliminary arrangements in connection with the works are being pressed forward as quickly as possible. When these matters have been disposed of the commissioners will be in a position to invite tenders. It is not possible at this stage to indicate a date for the commencement of the works.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Wexford Harbour Survey.

Speaker.hpid: Breanndán Mac Fheorais Breanndán Mac Fheorais
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Industry and Commerce if he has yet received the result of the hydrographic survey that was carried out in Wexford Harbour recently; and, if so, the nature of the report.

The hydrographic survey at Wexford Harbour has been completed and the chart prepared by the surveyors recording the results of the survey has been recently received by me. Copies of the chart have been sent to the harbour commissioners.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Electricity Supply Board Expenditure.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will state (a) the amount of money for capital expenditure that was given to the Electricity Supply Board for the year ending 31st March, 1951; (b) the total amount of interest paid or charged on the total capital advances outstanding for the year ending 31st March, 1951.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. MacEntee) Seán MacEntee
Speaker.P: During the year ended 31st March, 1951, advances from the Central Fund to the Electricity Supply Board for capital purposes amounted to £4,600,000, of which £1,400,000 was for rural electrification. Only 50 per cent. of the rural electrification advances are repayable by the board.
Interest paid by the board during the same period on the total repayable advances of £26,517,557 outstanding amounted to £965,088 2s. 0d.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Secondary Teachers' Income-Tax.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will state whether the retrospective payments by secondary teachers to gratuity and pensions funds will be allowable as deductions from salary for income-tax purposes in the year in which such arrears, or instalments thereof, are paid.

Presumably what the Deputy has in mind are retrospective payments under the Secondary Teachers' Superannuation (Amendment) Scheme, 1951. These payments will be allowable for income-tax purposes as deductions for the years in respect of which they are paid.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - State Lands.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance if he will state the total acreage of land held by the State or different Departments of State, for example, Moorepark, County Cork; Kilworth, County Cork; Ballincollig, County Cork; the Curragh, County Kildare; and whether there is any specific reason for the State continuing to hold these lands or any obstacle to their being handed over to the Land Commission for division into economic holdings and for the relief of congestion.

A figure for the acreage of all the lands held by the State or Departments of State is not readily available but the acreage of the lands which are not utilised for the specific purpose of the State is apparently what the Deputy has in mind. Such acreages are 823 acres in Moorepark, County Cork; 170 acres in Lusk Government Farm, County Dublin; and 140 acres in the Ballyfair estate, County Kildare. The enactment of enabling legislation would be required before these lands could be disposed of and proposals for this will be considered in due course. Some other lands, for example, 4,500 acres at Kilworth, County Cork; and 335 acres at Ballincollig, County Cork, are required for military purposes. Portion of the Curragh, County Kildare, known as the Greenlands is not used for such purposes. It contains 2,690 acres. The Greenlands, however, are subject to right of common of pasture exercised by a large number of persons occupying lands in the neighbourhood and there has been no question as to the suitability of any portion of the Curragh for transfer to the Land Commission.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Report on County Homes.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will make available to Deputies the recently drawn up report of the joint inter-departmental committee on present conditions in the county homes.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. Ryan) James Ryan
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is probably aware, it is not the usual practice to publish confidential reports of this nature, particularly before the responsible Minister or the Government have had an opportunity of considering and coming to a decision on the recommendations they contain. As I indicated in the Dáil last week, I propose to seek a Government decision on the recommendations contained in this report at an early date. When this has been done, I shall consider publishing a summary of the report.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Carlow County Hospital.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state the present position regarding the proposed new county hospital for Carlow and indicate the approximate date on which building will be commenced.

The present position regarding the proposed new county hospital at Carlow is that a detailed schedule of accommodation has been submitted by the local authority and is under examination in my Department. It will not be possible to complete this stage in the planning of the project until a final decision is made by the local authority as to the staffing of the institution. I understand that this matter is being actively pursued by the local authority.

I am not in a position at this stage to estimate when building will commence but my Department will endeavour to expedite as much as possible the completion of the further planning stages of the work.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hospital Accommodation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state the number of beds at present available in Dublin voluntary hospitals and in Dublin local authority hospitals for maternity cases; and, if some of these maternity beds are reserved for unmarried mothers, the number of beds so reserved.
I am informed that the number of beds available is 345 of which 16 are reserved specifically for unmarried mothers.
Is that between voluntary hospitals and local authority hospitals?
Yes.
Does the Minister agree that that is entirely inadequate to meet the present demand?
It is inadequate.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Crumlin-Kimmage Health Centre.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health when it is expected that the new health centre in the Crumlin-Kimmage area of Dublin referred to in his answer on the 10th July, 1951, will be available for use, and whether he is in a position to state the nature of the medical facilities that will be provided and the number of doctors and nurses that will be in attendance there.
I am informed that the Dublin Board of Assistance proposes to make the new health clinic in Crumlin available for use on the 1st August next.

The clinic will provide medical facilities at general practitioner level to persons who are entitled to medical assistance under the Public Assistance Act, 1939. Two doctors and two nurses will be in attendance at the clinic.

The Dublin Corporation also proposes to utilise the clinic for the holding of clinical sessions under its existing maternity and child welfare scheme, until such time as the health centre at present being built for the corporation in this area has been completed.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Immunisation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state the number of full immunisations against diphtheria carried out in the year 1950.
The number of complete immunisations carried out under diphtheria immunisation arrangements administered by health authorities during the year 1950 was 55,214.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Hospitalisation Programme.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state whether he proposes to continue the short-term seven years hospital reconstruction and erection programme as planned by the former Minister for Health; and, if not, if he will indicate in what respect he intends to alter or amend that programme and if he will state the number of hospitals to be (a) reconstructed, and (b) erected, under the programme and the number started to date and due to commence this year.
I have at present under consideration the hospital building programme to which the Deputy refers.

The number of hospitals to be reconstructed or extended under the programme is 128 and, of these, the number on which work has been completed or started to date is 62. Provision has been made in the programme for the erection of 37 hospitals, of which 20 have been completed or started to date. It is hoped that the reconstruction of 16 further hospitals and the erection of one hospital will be undertaken before the end of the year.
May we take it that it is not the intention of the Minister to reduce or cut down that building programme?
Certainly not to reduce.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Provision of Hospital Beds.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state the number of extra hospital beds provided in the year 1950 in (a) tuberculosis hospitals; (b) general hospitals, and (c) cancer hospitals or wards.
The number of extra hospital beds provided in the year 1950 in hospitals maintained by local authorities or in voluntary hospitals which furnish returns to the Hospitals Commission was as follows:—

MainHeading.P: The Deputy will understand that the number of extra beds provided in the year 1950 does not represent the amount of hospital building work carried out in that year. The building works at present in progress will provide, on completion, 1,788 extra beds in tuberculosis hospitals, 863 extra beds in general hospitals and 160 extra beds in cancer hospitals, as well as a much improved standard of accommodation in those hospitals which are being reconstructed.
The figures which I have given in relation to general hospitals do not include maternity hospitals, fever hospitals, orthopaedic hospitals or mental defective institutions.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Kildare Dispensary Survey.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he will state when he expects to be in a position to give to the Kildare County Council the result of the pilot survey of dispensary districts within the county.

It would be premature to convey to the council the suggestions contained in the survey report until final decisions have been taken on proposals for the expansion of health services as such decisions could affect the recommendations made in the report.
Can the Minister say when the survey was made?
In 1947, I think. It was made when I was there anyway.
A good deal before 1947, I think.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Accommodation for Nurses.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health if he is aware that considerable inconvenience is caused to the nursing sisters attached to the County Hospital, Tralee, by reason of the fact that there is lack of suitable living accommodation there and, further, if he will approve of the proposals submitted to him by the Kerry County Council in connection with their proposal to build living quarters for nurses.

I am aware that suitable living accommodation is not available for the nursing sisters attached to the county hospital and on the 10th March, 1950, a proposal of the local authority to erect a convent was approved in principle.

A sketch design for a new convent to accommodate 30 sisters was submitted on 12th June, 1951, and has been under examination in my Department. In order to complete the examination of the sketch design it has been necessary to request, on 11th July, 1951, the submission of a preliminary estimate of cost and recommendations for the civil and mechanical engineering services. On receipt of this information observations on the sketch design will be issued to the local authority without delay.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Type of Birth Certificate.

I think I should be in a position to introduce the legislation referred to in the next Session.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - Organisation of Arbor Week.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Lands whether he is prepared to give his support and that of the Forestry Division to the organisation of an Arbor Week.

The expansion of afforestation is an important feature of Government policy. While the main object is the establishment of the maximum area under State forests, the Government is also anxious to encourage and foster the planting of trees by private individuals and groups of individuals. In many areas there is a tendency to assume that tree-planting is the duty or responsibility of the Forestry Division only, and anything which would make the community as a whole, appreciate the benefits and importance of private tree-planting, is deserving of every support.

A successful Arbor Week could do much to promote tree-planting as a matter of course and also awaken a desire to maintain our already inadequate woodlands. It is essential, however, that such a project should be carefully planned to ensure that the selection of sites, fencing, plant selection and planting would be properly done. The forestry staff of my Department will give any advice and assistance that may be needed on these important matters. My general support can be counted upon.
Would it be possible for the Minister and the Department, instead of giving advice, to give a lead in this important matter?

I do not quite know what kind of lead the Deputy would suggest. This is supposed to be a voluntary undertaking. To the extent that we are in a position to give advice or assistance we will do everything possible. If we are to give up the idea of having an Arbor Week voluntarily organised and supported, that is quite a different matter.

Would it not be possible for the Minister and the Department, through communications with various county committees of agriculture, to stir up a little more voluntary activity in the various counties? Could there not be a genuine national lead from the Department?

I can quite see the Deputy's point of view but I can assure him that the forestry inspectors and staff are very busy men at the present time and I doubt very much that Deputies would be pleased with me if I were to take them from the duties upon which they are busily engaged at present to put them organising this work. I have indicated in my reply that I am willing to give all the assistance possible.

I wonder would the Minister consider discussing the matter with the Minister for Education with a view to requesting the schools to take local initiative in the matter of promoting local Arbor Weeks? Schools could be of tremendous assistance.
Certainly. I would be very pleased to mention the matter to the Minister for Education. I think, however, the initiative must come from those voluntary bodies who are interested.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - National Flag and Proclamation.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education whether he will make available to all national schools suitably framed copies of the Proclamation of 1916, and request that these be displayed in all the classrooms.

asked the Minister for Education whether he is prepared to consider the desirability of flying the National Flag during school hours from a pole provided for the purpose in each national school and to urge the formal hoisting and lowering of the flag daily in the presence of all the children and teachers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Moylan) Seán Moylan
Speaker.P: With the permission of the Ceann Comhairle, I propose to take Questions Nos. 49 and 50 together.

If, as I would conclude, the Deputy is concerned for the growth and development of a spirit of patriotism among the pupils of our primary schools, I cannot agree that the procedure suggested offers the most effective means towards achieving that end. Patriotism should be a natural and progressive growth in our schools and the less it is inculcated through the medium of the formality which characterises most school tasks the more likely it is to take firm root in the mind and heart, and to establish itself as an influence in future conduct.

A sound knowledge of the national and cultural inheritance that has come down to us is, to my mind, the surest foundation for a spirit of patriotism. Regard and respect for the Proclamation of 1916 and the National Flag will naturally find their place in every scheme of instruction directed towards laying such a foundation, but I do not consider that symbols of national significance should be made a matter of such every-day familiarity that reverence for them would become superficial, mechanical and meaningless.

MainHeading.P: I do not, therefore, intend to act in this matter as the Deputy appears to recommend. I am strengthened in my attitude by the consideration that my Department is most careful to refrain from imposing regulations on the schools other than those which concern matters hitherto neglected or unprovided for.

Speaker.P: I take it the Minister has noticed that I did not suggest that there should be any regulation made in the matter. I am merely suggesting that that proposal should come forward from the Department of Education to the schools. I wonder could the Minister tell the House where a child at school is likely to learn of the Proclamation of 1916 or to see it if he does not see it at school?
I think in the ordinary teaching of history in the schools such learning would come better than from the manner the Deputy suggests.

I wonder would the Minister tell the House where a child at school will learn of the Proclamation of 1916 or learn of the manner in which he should treat the flag of the country if he does not learn it at school?

I have suggested to the Deputy that I do not think that any method such as is used to inculcate the ordinary school subjects into the minds of the pupils is really the best method to utilise in inculcating the patriotism such as he and I desire. I do not believe in the method of doing it. That method is very much in vogue in America, but the American problem is completely different in so far as school-children in America come from homes of so many different nationalities with so many different traditions, and in America the Government, apparently, do consider that the main problem is trying to make Americans of children of a number of varying nationalities. We have not that problem here and I do not think we should adopt the method the Deputy suggests.

MainHeading.Title: Statement by Ceann Comhairle.

Speaker.P: The point raised by Deputy Dillon on Thursday concerning certain words which, he alleged, were unwarrantedly inserted by the Taoiseach into the Official Report of 4th July, is one for the Chair to deal with rather than the Taoiseach. Deputy Dillon should, therefore, have raised it initially as a matter of privilege and not as a charge against a Minister in the course of a debate on a Government motion. I find from inquiries that the words “in reply to some things that have been said” were proposed to be inserted at the instance of the Taoiseach. The notetaker had not recorded them but, as they did not appear to make any alteration of meaning in the statement made by the Taoiseach, the editor decided, in his discretion, to authorise their insertion. Any proposed alteration of substance would be brought to my attention but, in fact, this matter did not come to my notice until Deputy Dillon raised it in the Dáil. Having considered the point fully and carefully, I agree with the editor's judgment in this case. The introductory words used by the Taoiseach at the time were obviously intended to catch my attention as I was on the point of rising to put the question and their phraseology did not seem of significance.
Am I supposed to comment on that?
No.

Because if I am afforded an opportunity of commenting on it, I want to say that I propose this evening to make it quite manifest to the House that the words are words of substance and that they were inserted by the Taoiseach for the purpose of tricking the House and justifying a very dirty transaction in which he had taken part earlier in the day.
